explanation:
Reasoning for required symbols (concise):
- All direct callees of OS_CleanUpObject (OS_IdentifyObject, OS_TaskDelete, OS_QueueDelete, OS_BinSemDelete, OS_CountSemDelete, OS_MutSemDelete, OS_ModuleUnload, OS_TimeBaseDelete, OS_TimerDelete, OS_close, OS_DirectoryClose, OS_CondVarDelete): these functions are executed from within OS_CleanUpObject. Any for-loop present in their bodies contributes to the behaviour of the call site and must be inspected for MISRA for-loop well-formedness.
- Corresponding _Impl functions (e.g. OS_TaskDelete_Impl, OS_QueueDelete_Impl, OS_BinSemDelete_Impl, OS_CountSemDelete_Impl, OS_MutSemDelete_Impl, OS_ModuleUnload_Impl, OS_TimeBaseDelete_Impl, OS_TimerDelete_Impl, OS_GenericClose_Impl, OS_DirClose_Impl, OS_CondVarDelete_Impl): implementations often contain the actual loop constructs and internal logic; examine them for for-loops and whether loop counters/flags are correctly used and not modified outside the loop control clauses.
- OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete and other OS_ObjectId* helpers (OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl, OS_ObjectIdFromToken, OS_ObjectIdTransferToken, OS_ObjectIdEqual, OS_ObjectIdRelease, OS_ObjectIdDefined): these helpers are called by many of the delete/close routines and may either contain for-loops themselves or modify objects that could be used as loop counters/flags in surrounding code. They must be checked to ensure they do not introduce side-effects that would break the MISRA for-loop clause rules when invoked from within loops.
- OS_TaskGetId_Impl, OS_TimeBaseLock_Impl, OS_TimeBaseUnlock_Impl: used by timebase/timer-related callees; they may contain synchronization loops or counter manipulations relevant to for-loop correctness.
- UT_* stub helpers (UT_ExecuteBasicHandler, UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType, UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData, UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr): these appear in the static call graph for many callees. Although test-stub utilities often do not contain production for-loops, they can alter control flow/return values or introduce loops in instrumented builds; include them to be sure no for-loops violating the rule are injected via testing layers.

In short: to determine whether OS_CleanUpObject violates the MISRA for-loop rule you must inspect every function it calls (and their implementations and common helper routines) because any for-loop in those functions or in helpers contributes to the effective behaviour at the OS_CleanUpObject call sites and could contain loop counters or side-effects that would breach the three-clause and single-counter requirements.
